thread.title: NASA unveils dazzling mosaics of Pluto
thread.title_full: NASA unveils dazzling mosaics of Pluto

author: Deccan
title: NASA unveils dazzling mosaics of Pluto
text:
Deccan Chronicle | October 21, 2015, 21.43 pm The mosaics include dim skies on Earth, landmarks, selfies, family and even pets (Photo credit: NASA) Mumbai: National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) on Wednesday unveiled mosaics of Pluto and its largest moon Charon, indicating the high global response to its popular social media campaign "#PlutoTime".
The New Horizons science team developed the Pluto Time concept and widget, allowing people from all over the globe to experience the estimated sunlight level on Pluto at noon—usually around dawn or dusk on Earth.
After the campaign was announced in June, NASA received as many as 3,39,000 visits to the Pluto Time Widget and approximately 7,000 images were submitted by individuals from across the globe.
Thousands of those submissions have now been assembled into three stunning mosaics of Pluto, Charon, and a combined image of the two.
The mosaics include not only dim skies on Earth, but prominent landmarks, selfies, family and even pets. Interestingly, the files are so large that at the current resolution, they would make an 11 x 11' print.
The concept and initiation of the social media campaign was a result of a frequently asked question of New Horizon Scientists: how are you going to take pictures of Pluto, given that it's so far from the sun?
"We realized that we could make a web tool that would estimate approximately when the light levels dropped to Pluto levels," said Alex Parker, research scientist at the Southwest Research Institute (SwRI) in Boulder, Colorado.
"We looked up tables of illumination levels during various stages of twilight—used to determine when streetlights come on and such—and determined how low the sun would need to be on a clear day to match Pluto. After that is was a matter of doing the math,” he added.
The Solar System Exploration Public Engagement team at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) were responsible for attaching the mosaics, using approximately 1,500 to 2,000 images for each.
The creators of the mosaic have also given their tributes to Clyde Tombaugh, the man responsible for the discovery of Pluto in 1930. Zooming in the adjacent image will show a picture of Tombaugh and his homemade 9-inch telescope in the region of Pluto’s heart, which is informally named Tombaugh Regio.
"It's gratifying to see the global response to Pluto Time, which allowed us to imagine what it's like on Pluto, some three billion miles away," said Jim Green, NASA's director of planetary science. "This is a wonderful example of how space exploration and science unite us with a common bond."
To experience Pluto Time where you live, click on the link below:
http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/plutotime
